text-0-1: Fundasil in support of the Spotlight Initiative
text-10-2: Among the principles of self-care, some of the following elements should be considered when addressing it (Uribe, 1999; Correa, 2016):
text-10-3: It is a life act that enables individuals to become active participants in the care of their health and is a voluntary process undertaken by the person for themselves.
text-10-4: It is an individual responsibility and a daily commitment grounded in both a formal and informal health system with social support.
text-10-5: When engaging in self-care practices, whether for protective or preventive purposes, individuals undertake them with the certainty that they will enhance their level of health.
text-10-6: For self-care to occur, a certain degree of personal development is required, which is mediated by the continuous strengthening of self-concept, self-control, self-esteem, self-acceptance, and resilience.
text-11-10: One example is the establishment of boundaries that separate work life from personal life. Some individuals choose not to respond to messages and calls outside of working hours, while others, due to their position or profession, cannot make that decision and opt for other measures. The important thing is to respect their needs.
text-11-12: The individual learns to say no to less important matters and focuses on goals that foster growth, maintaining a healthy state that allows for optimal performance.
text-11-13: These decisions have an impact on others; by being focused, the individual performs better in areas such as work or family, but primarily, the impact occurs on the person who incorporates these behaviors into their life.
text-11-14: The incorporation of self-care behaviors enhances productivity: if there is a review of needs and a consequent establishment of boundaries, the most important ones are prioritized.
text-11-2: Incorporating self-care routines is key to improving quality of life and preventing both physical and mental illnesses (such as anxiety, depression, among others), as well as for recovery in the event of experiencing them.
text-11-3: In fact, it has been identified that incorporating these practices leads to greater adherence to therapeutic treatments among patients with chronic illnesses (Bastidas, 2007).
text-11-4: This facilitates the restoration of health and empowers the individual, providing them with more resources and control over the situation affecting their well-being.
text-11-5: Learning to care for oneself is a way to improve one's relationship with oneself; it involves gaining a better understanding of oneself and knowing which practices and interests contribute to one's own health.
text-11-6: Self-care invites individuals to reflect on what truly inspires and excites them, helping to better understand the physical, social, cognitive, and emotional needs that contribute to their well-being.
text-11-7: These efforts and care convey a message about the value we place on health and self-care, allowing us to see the importance of the individual; generally speaking, it can be said that it improves self-esteem.
text-11-8: Having a greater self-awareness and valuing one's own needs promotes decision-making and the establishment of boundaries, both for oneself and towards others.
text-11-9: In essence, it involves recognizing one's own abilities and respecting one's well-being.
text-12-1: In others, the impact is evident not only in increased productivity,
text-12-2: but also in the improvement of interpersonal relationships,
text-12-3: as it involves working on aspects such as emotional management and the ability to resolve conflicts.
text-12-4: Self-care is not about engaging in isolated care activities without purpose.
text-12-5: The objective is to take responsibility for one's own health and, in many cases, to initiate a process of personal work.
text-12-6: Which can take quite some time.
text-13-12: Many daily care activities are unconscious, but self-care involves becoming aware of these activities and acting accordingly.
text-13-13: Eating occurs every day, and often the body's nutritional needs are not considered.
text-13-14: It may not be the healthiest food, or the quantities may be inadequate.
text-13-18: While self-care is a daily commitment, it must adapt to the circumstances and needs of the moment and can vary in both practices and schedules.
text-13-2: There are certain myths about self-care that we need to address and clarify.
text-13-7: Taking care of oneself is not an act of selfishness; it is about taking responsibility for one's health and exercising the right to preserve it.
text-13-8: It involves striving to be well for oneself, as one cannot care for others if not well oneself.
text-14-11: Myth: Self-care is equivalent to resting
text-14-13: Resting is an obligation for maintaining health and requires engaging in activities aimed at preserving well-being, which are not always associated with rest.
text-14-14: Exercising, studying, and using free time for engaging in a playful learning activity are some of the options.
text-14-16: Self-care is a habit that is developed.
text-14-18: Self-care is becoming aware of our positive behaviors and, consequently, making evident the needs that must be addressed through practices that need to be developed.
text-14-2: Self-care is always doing what is best for oneself.
text-14-4: It is prioritizing one's health and acting accordingly.
text-14-5: It is not about forcing oneself to do something unenjoyable; rather, it is about ensuring it aligns with personal interests, goals, and needs.
text-14-9: While there are activities that require the investment of material resources, there are free alternatives, but we must be willing to invest time.
text-15-2: There are different ways to categorize self-care behaviors; the effort can be individual or collective.
text-15-4: is often the most understood and widespread form of self-care and consists of all the measures adopted by the individual as the manager of their health.
text-15-5: That is, the behaviors carried out independently by being aware of one's needs and the importance of ensuring time is dedicated to fulfilling them.
text-16-10: participate in gatherings related to common interests
text-16-11: such as sharing impressions of a movie or a book,
text-16-12: among other activities that seek the common well-being.
text-16-13: These categories demonstrate that taking responsibility for health is a task that arises from the individual,
text-16-14: but involves sharing collectively as it deepens.
text-16-15: It is common for there to always be aspects that need to be changed in the environment.
text-16-16: to achieve sustainable efforts and a truly healthy environment.
text-16-2: It can be considered as the extension of individual self-care towards others,
text-16-3: as it refers to actions that are planned and developed in cooperation,
text-16-4: among the members of a community, family, or group,
text-16-5: who build a physical and social, emotional and supportive space.
text-17-1: Another way to categorize self-care emerges when addressing the comprehensive aspect of health.
text-17-10: Caring for relationships, as well as becoming aware of the impact that certain relationships or societal influences may have on oneself.
text-17-11: Connecting with one's own values and maintaining a healthy relationship with one's inner self.
text-17-12: Spiritual self-care: it is the connection with oneself, with one's values and beliefs,
text-17-2: There is a categorization of care according to the various dimensions and needs of the human being, highlighting physical, emotional, cognitive, social, and even spiritual needs.
text-17-4: is everything related to the well-being of the body, which involves having a healthy diet, hygiene habits, and an appropriate sleep regimen, maintaining physical activity, as well as preventing and properly addressing any illness or discomfort.
text-17-5: Emotional self-care: involves connecting with one's own emotions and those of others, accepting that they are part of life and do not define us.
text-17-6: It is learning that one is not to blame for their own emotions, but is responsible for the actions that arise from them.
text-17-7: Cognitive self-care: it is essential to exercise our intellectual faculties, to stimulate critical thinking, creativity, and other inherent competencies.
text-17-8: Learning and developing skills that are of interest to the individual.
text-17-9: Healthy bonds and connections should be built, a support network that allows the individual to remain healthy.
